授業目的:
This course will provide you with an in-depth understanding of the forces shaping
contemporary Japan. In order to understand Japan as it is today, we will explore the
socio political forces that have shaped Japanese society. Along the way, we will explore
how choices made in the adoption of social policy have created a very distinct political
system. Furthermore, we will discuss how both traditional and current expressions of
culture weigh heavy in the politics of Japan.
We will start the course by becoming familiar with the most important actors and
institutions shaping Japanese politics. We will then study how these actors and
institutions interact with ideology, identity, and economic forces to shape how political
events unfold. From there, we will focus our attention on the big problems facing the
country, these include: the struggling economy, an aging population, welfare,
healthcare, and gender and sexuality issues. Specifically, we will pay close attention to
the role of public policy reforms in immigration, education, environment, and social
services. Then, we will explore how such issues manifest themselves in contemporary
culture.
到達目標:
・Understand the main forces shaping contemporary Japanese Society.
・Understand how Japanese policymakers think about addressing the countries main challenges. Such as, economic growth, aging population, welfare policy, climate change, and migration among others.
・Learn how social issues are interconnected and how solving one issue can exacerbate another.

授業方法:
PARTICIPATION, ATTENDANCE, AND ENGAGEMENT
You will be ready to participate actively in discussions. We expect you to be engaged
and attentive. You must understand that we are in a different cultural space, body
language is important and you must be aware of how your behavior is perceived and
affects others.
You will be expected to come to class prepared to discuss the assigned readings for the
day, participate actively in class discussions, and as often as applicable, be able to
relate the material to current events. If you are absent for 5 or more classes, you will
receive an F for the course.
